title: Jack's Battle with COVID-19 and Aftermath
clinical_history: Jack is a 42-year-old IT consultant who developed symptoms of COVID-19 two months ago. His initial symptoms included fever, cough, and a general feeling of unwellness. Four days later, he experienced difficulty breathing and was admitted to the hospital where he tested positive for the coronavirus. After a week in the hospital, including three days in the ICU, Jack's condition stabilized and he was discharged to quarantine at home. Despite recovery from the acute phase of the illness, he continues to experience lingering symptoms, including fatigue and shortness of breath upon exertion. Jack expresses concerns regarding muscle weakness, particularly in his thighs, and complains of joint pain in his knees and elbows. These symptoms are adversely impacting his ability to return to work and partake in everyday activities.

nprs.affected_area: joint pain in knees and elbows

aggrevating_factors: extended periods of standing, climbing stairs, and attempts to resume moderate-intensity exercise routines
easing_factors: rest breaks during activities, over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen
past_history: Jack has no significant medical history apart from seasonal allergies. He was physically active prior to his illness, often jogging three times a week.
medical_history: recent diagnosis of post-COVID-19 syndrome (Long COVID), no other underlying health conditions identified pre-COVID-19
medications: vitamin D supplements as advised by his doctor, acetaminophen for joint pain management as needed
personal_history: lives with his partner in a suburban neighborhood. They enjoy outdoor activities together but have reduced these due to Jack's health status. He maintains a balanced diet and is now considering incorporating more immune-boosting foods after his illness.
imaging: chest X-ray conducted during hospitalization showed bilateral lung infiltrates consistent with viral pneumonia, now resolved.
